title: Visualizing qualitative patterns in multivariate time series

author: Luka Stopar, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: Welcome, members of the committee welcome everybody.
Thank you for coming.
My name is Lucas Topper are present.
The work that we did for my PhD.
Which is entitled visualizing qualitative patterns in multivariate time series.
Which we did under the supervision of Professor Doctor Doom Laden each and Professor Doctor Primo Scrubber.
This is the outline of the talk.
So first I'll present some motivation.
Or then a brief overview of the approach.
Then I'll state the hypothesis and then we go through the scientific contributions.
We'll look at the evaluation and then we'll conclude and look at the publications.

So multivariate time series are abundant in many research and engineering applications, but the standard methods for visualizing them are not satisfactory because first they produce clutter when visualizing large datasets.
So we get something like this here.
Or they fail to highlight the interaction between the variables and they become difficult to interpret even when visualizing data of medium dimensionality.
So to to analyze such datasets, users have to zoom into interesting intervals.
Or isolate the variables that are informative and then remove clutter manually and each step causes a context switch which hinders their productivity.
Now our approach it first abstracts.
So we present an approach for abstraction and visualization of such datasets.
So our approach abstracts the data into States and transitions.
And it produces a hierarchical representation, so the users can can look at the data on many levels of detail.

Our hypothesis are free fold so first that combining techniques from machine learning, data mining and statistics into a tool for data abstraction and visualization can highlight the long term behavior of a data set and explore and expose her recurrent patterns while mitigating cluttering effects.
Typical when visualizing large datasets.

2nd that long term and recurrent patterns can emerge on different spatial granularities, which we call scales and that traversing the scales interactively provides an effective way or to identify where such patterns emerge.
Confirmed that the visual abstractions that summarize the structure can be mapped back to domain specific concepts by quantitative tools.
Our scientific contributions are also free fold, so first is a methodology for multivariate time series abstraction visualization and multiscale exploration.
2nd is a novel visualization approach that allows the user to explore the structure and the long-term behavior of the data set.
And third, fully interactive web based visualization tool.
So we'll go through all of these three in more depth in more detail.
Now we we construct.
Four step methodology to construct this abstraction.
The first step is static time series embedding.
Then in the second step we construct the states.
In the third step, we construct the transitions between the States and then in the fourth step we construct the hierarchy of such representations.
The inputs to the first step is a time series which is represented with the.
Where which is represented as a sequence of tuples, where each tuple consists of a timestamp and a measurement.
And we assume that this measurement has dimension more than one.
The output of this first step is a point cloud, so a sequence of points.
Where time is not explicitly represented.
Also we this each point also has dimension more than one.
And we augment this representation with historical and some temporal information.
To construct this embedding, we define.
Component embedding function, where this first component encodes information about the current measurement.
Or this second component encodes information about the current timestamp so we can use this to encode, for example, the day of the week, or maybe the hour of the day.
And then this third component encodes information about the historical measurements.
So here we can include something like either the derivative or some other information.
In the next step, we.
We abstract the point cloud from the first step into into states.
Basically, a state represents a typical configuration of the temporal signal, and it summarizes the structure around its center.
The states are constructed by by partitioning the space into Voronoi cells and then associating each Voronoi cell with the state.
And the output of this of this step is a matrix of centroids, where then each point is assigned to the nearest centroid based on some metric.
In the third step, we reintroduced the temporal dynamics as the transitions between the states, so we get something like this.
Now here the transitions.
They basically summarize the trajectory data Time series took through these regions of the ambient space in the historical data.

So we model the transitions as a continuous time Markov chain, which basically assumes that this transition process is memoryless, so that once the process is in a state, it has no idea how long it's been there.
And on and the next.
The next state where it's going to go is independent of where it's been.
Or we make two further assumptions on the Markov chain.
So first is that the chain itself is not explosive, which means that it cannot make an infinite number of jumps in a finite time interval.
And the second one is that the chain is recurrent, which means that you can get from any state to any other state with a positive probability.
The key advantages of using Markov chains.
Our first that.
The representation is compact, so we get the whole representation just with the matrix.
2nd, we can compute several long term properties of the process by just linear algebra operations, so we can, for example, compute the stationary distribution Pi here.
By solving this eigenvalue problem.
On and this static distribution basically tells us how much time the process spends in each of the states.
Now the output of this third step is a matrix of transition rates Q.
So now that we have the States and transitions, we aggregate this representation into a hierarchy.
Basically creating a hierarchical partition of this space.
We do this by aggregating adjacent states.
And then when we aggregate the states, we compute the transition rate between two aggregated states A&B.
Using this explicit formula here.
So this formula basically for each state in a or it takes the probability of being in a, which is this P. And then sums up sums up the intensities of going into each, stating B.
That's just some here.
And then all this is normalized by the probability of being a.
No Toto.
Instruct the actual topology of the hierarchy.
We use two approaches, or we support we support two approaches.
The first one is mean linkage agglomerative clustering, which represents the distance based approach.
And it works by iteratively merging the pair of states with the nearest centroids.
The second one is iterative mean cut based splitting, which is a transition based approach.
Basically, this approach assumes that each state has a Markov chain of its own.
On and then it starts with a single state and then iteratively splits one of the states on the transitions which are in the mean cut.
So we move on to the visual representation.
So here 1st I'll give an overview of what the representation looks like.
Then we look at each of the visual elements separately in more detail.
Then we'll see how we encode the hierarchical relationships, and then how we generate automatic state labels.
Also, we draw the time series as a static graph like this here with several of zero auxiliary views.
So we we represent this states as nodes in the graph like this here and we represent the transitions as edges here.
The hierarchical structure is shown at a single scale, but then the user can switch the scales interactively by using the scroll function.
On and then we use the auxiliary views to visualize first the sequence of states on a linear temporal axis.
So the typical times when a state occurs and configuration of the attributes in a state.
Like I mentioned before, the States summarize regions of the ambient space.
We visualize them as circles, and we encode 5 properties.
So we set the radius so that the area of the state is linearly proportional to the time that the process spends in the state.
So these bigger circles represent states where the process spends more time.
On the position of the state, it reflects the position of the state in the original space relative to the other states.
Color and close the hierarchical relationship between states.
And the label highlights spatial and temporal granularities of the states.
And then finally a blue border indicates the state that's currently selected.
Next, the transition summarize the trajectory of the time series through the regions of the ambient space, or we draw them with three properties.
1st is the label that encodes the probability of the associated transition.
So like we see here.
Next is the color which we use to reduce clutter.
We do this by making the more probable transitions darker than the less probable ones.
And then finally we use shape to further reduce clutter.
So basically the transitions that are very unlikely have dashed.
Best slang?
We use an icicle plot on the bottom to visualize the sequence of states, as it occurred historically on a linear temporal axis.
We link this representation it interactively to the main graph based representation and we associate states by color.
So basically the purple states here is the same as the purple states up there.
And this view can be used to analyze historical phenomena so the user can zoom into here and see which sequences of states occur.
We use time histograms to visualize when a state typically occurs.
So for example, in which day of the week or which month of the year?
So here we see that this green state here, it's mostly occurred in the summer months.
And this purple state here at mostly occurred in the winter months.
We we visualize four temporal granularities, daily, weekly, monthly and yearly.
The state layout reflects the position of the states relative to each other in the ambient space.
It works by first projecting the lowest scale states.

Onto the plane via MDS and it then positions the coarser scale states by computing a weighted average of the position of the children is here and we use entries in the stationary distribution as weights.
So the intuition here is that the states where the process spends spends more time will be more stable through the hierarchy.
And then in the end we follow this up with the cross scale repulsive scheme so that we ensure that no states overlap in the final representation.
We use color coding to encode the states position in the hierarchy.
So first Hue encodes the proximity of the states on the same scale.
So basically on the states in the same subtree of the hierarchy will have more similar color than states in different subtrees.

So in this example here we can see that this free green states they came by splitting apart this green state here and these two blue states they came by splitting this blue state here, and likewise for the purple ones.
Then we also use saturation to encode the state scale.
So that the lowest lower scale states will be more saturated than course or scale states.
We can see this here, or these finer states are have more color than these states here, so these are more greyish.
And then we also generate automatic labels for the states.
So we generate two types of labels.
First are the spatial labels that highlights the.
The attributes that are characteristic for the state.
So in this example here we see that this rainfall here is on the real really on the high edge of the distribution.
So this state is in code has labeled rainfall highest.
The second type are temporal labels, where we encode when the states typically occurs.
Now for this example here we see that the state only occurs in October, so it's labeled October.
Cancel moving on to the visualization tool here.
I've prepared the demo.
OK, so this is what the tool looks like.
This is the dashboard.
It has two main panels.
So here we have the data sets of the current user.
Then here we have some public datasets.
Now to visualize the new data set, we click the add button here.
And we have to select the data set.
We we support CSV files.
So we select this data set here.
Then we need to select which attributes we want to visualize.
When we use all of them.
We need to select the time attribute and then just to help.
To help make the text nicer, we need to select the temporal granularity.
So here we have seasonal data, so we'll select month.
And there's some other configuration.
Here we configured the clustering algorithm algorithm and generation of the hierarchy.
We give it the name.
So now we can view it.
So on a high level here we have two states 11.
Is labeled rainfall high?
OK.
This one is labeled rainfall high.
This one is labeled rent called low rainfall low and we can see that the distribution of rainfall and temperature is both high.
Actually in this data set, they really correlate highly.
We can check the time when it occurs.
So this one occurs in more in the winter months and the other one more in the summer months.
And now we can zoom into this model, right?
So first it breaks up into four states.

We have this hot state here in this cold state here and then we have some intermediate states, so with kind of moderate temperature and rainfall and a bit lower but still in the middle of the distribution.
And we can check when these two states occurs.
So this one is March, April and then November in December.
So just after winter and just before summer.
Just before winter and just.
Just before winter and just after winter and then this one is just before summer and just after summer.
Now if we zoom in further, this starts breaking up into into a cycle.
Here we get the perfect cycle.
Now this cycle here it indicates a periodic process, so the data just goes around in a circle.
We can also visualize the attributes across scales, so we can for example, visualize temperature.
We got like high temperature, abit lower low temperature and then moderate.
And then if we zoom in further here, we find that the summer is really stable and the winter is a bit more stable.
So here from this state we can either go here or here.
And then from this state we can either go back or forward.
So we.
We used four datasets to demonstrate how to find and interpret the long term behavior of the data.
So for example, here in the traffic data set we found free cycles organized in a Figure 8 pattern.
Where this song?
This first cycle here.
It's represents the night cycle where we go from moderate traffic to very low traffic and then to high traffic in the morning.
This middle blue cycle.
Here it represents the mid day cycle where we go from high traffic to moderate traffic and then to high traffic again and then this red cycle here.
It represents the afternoon cycle, which is from moderate traffic to the most extreme traffic.
So to the highest traffic and then back.
We map the elements of the abstractions back to the main concepts by interpreting each of the models, and we showed how traversing the scales can reveal the structure in the data.

So here in this wind data set on one of the lowest scales, we found this free group structure where one group corresponds to strong type of Morrowind and the other one to a week type, and then the third group is come wins, which is most typical.
We compare their representation to the representation of time curves.
Here we found that or that.
Basically when visualizing data using time curves, large datasets tend to produce clutter and that we cannot map the elements of the visual.
Representation back to the main concepts.
So this is the representation here.
On the other hand, our our representation tends to remove a lot of information, which is especially problematic when visualizing small datasets.
During the development of the tool, we gathered feedback from the main experts on in two iterations or two stages.
Now the first stage showed that.
Or that the domain experts had a lot of trouble interpreting the representation with only States and transitions.
So then then we upgraded the representation we added on.
Like the bicycle plot on the bottom and automatic labels, and then in the second iteration, the domain experts could.
Had much less trouble interpreting the representation so they could interpret the typical States and then some of them could even interpret the cyclic patterns.
We found that machine learning tools like decision trees just confused the domain experts and were of no use to them.
So in conclusion, we presented a novel methodology for abstraction and visualization of multivariate time series.
We presented a novel visualization approach.
We demonstrated its utility on four real world datasets and we confirmed our hypothesis through experiments.
Phone how how we got.
Care so we first.
Develop a search engine extension, just called Search point that groups it groups textual documents by topic, then displays the topics like this here.
And it allows the user to reorder search results by moving this focus points to one of the topics.
We then extended this.
Extended search point to news corpora and we also added the ranking by sentiment and geographical location.
And we contributed to the open source analytics library called Q Minor.
We got the publications in some excellent journals.
Thank you very much.
